Author: rokhayakebe
Content:
it is like being an artist (let's say a painter). You spend 9 months day in and day out painting a "Mona Lisa". You better make sure all the notables like your work. If not you may as well have been working for the love of it because the guys who walk in the gallery will only eat your cheese, drink your wine, have a quick look at your painting and at best comment about it. But no money will be spent. Well unless you manage to sell them premium wine and cheese.

EDIT: @Diego. Had I read you comment, I would probably write mine differently. Apologies.

Author: kungfooey
Content: Seriously! That's exactly what I thought. I'm a (married) consultant living in Queens. I work at businesses all over Manhattan and I find that I'm the only guy bagging my own lunch (seriously - never seen anybody else do it in the two years I've been doing this here). I'm from the south, so I find the NYC idea of "budgeting" to be absolutely laughable.

Author: schtog
Title: Ask HN: good place to store code online?
Content:
what is the best place to store code online? i want to have a backup of my files somewhere in case something happens and an emailadress is just annoying for this kind of thing.

i could use google doc to save the soource code but i just want to be able to store it as a .py-file or .scm-file and download directly later.

mozy seem to cost even for the smallest storage? xdrive has 5GB free though.

any tips? should obv support any fileformat.

Author: nreece
Title: The creator of Ruby explains why Ruby sucks

Author: yan
Content:
I think asking what a high level language is akin to asking "What is tall?" If you're talking about buildings, tall can mean one thing, if you're talking about toddlers, tall can mean another. Haskell can seem like a low-level language to, say, English.

A "level" of a language is a very relative concept, but you can approximately define a hierarchy of languages relating the level of one language to another using some arbitrary comparison.

Since my background is in operating systems and some compilers, I'd say anything C and anything higher level is "high level," but then again, that can mean anything :)

Author: senthil_rajasek
Title: In '4-G' wireless race, first to market may not win
Content: The wireless industry's move to faster networks represents the next big battleground in the fight for market share. Since most Americans already subscribe to a mobile plan, carriers will have to poach customers from rivals or get them to pay more to keep revenue flowing -- and growing.

Author: edw519
Content: Never said how many 18 to 20 hour days. Depending on this answer, this could be an excellent setup for a software startup. Work double shifts during planting and harvesting, single shift and part time the rest of the year. Live for free, write software the rest of the time. Bank everything. All you'd need is broadband and some deposit slips. By the time your software was done, you could be your own angel.

Author: jpeterson
Content: YC companies have a ready market of potential buyers because of pg's credibility. Building-to-sell would be significantly riskier and less strategically sound for a non-YC company.

Author: JacobAldridge
Content:
I think there are probably two schools of thought here. Steve Barsh argues you need to define your customer, their problem, and your extremely compelling solution, then code.

PG tends to argue the other way - code first, release early, GET USERS, and then have them define the solution they need.

Working with a number of businesses I don't think there's a right or wrong. The risk with Steve's method is inbuilt assumptions you can make answering his questions, long before a real person ever sits in front of your program.
